description: Some say from Scots glamer, supposedly from earlier Scots gramarye (“magic, enchantment, spell”).

According to George Mpampiniotis, a glossology professor at the University of Athens, the Scottish term may either be from the Greek word Γραμματική (grammatiki - grammar).  
A connection has also been suggested with Old Norse glámr (poet. “moon,” name of a ghost) and glámsýni (“glamour, illusion”, literally “glam-sight”). From Grettir's Saga aka Grettis Saga, one of the Sagas of Icelanders, after the hero has been cursed by Glam, aka Glamr:
"...he was become so fearsome a man in the dark, that he durst go nowhither alone after nightfall, for then he seemed to see all kinds of horrors.
And that has fallen since into a proverb, that Glam lends eyes, or gives Glamsight to those who see things nowise as they are."
Glamsight (glámsýni) is also referred to in the Icelandic collection Sturlunga saga.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Originally, enchantment; magic charm; especially, the effect of a spell that causes one to see objects in a form that differs from reality, typically to make filthy, ugly, or repulsive things seem beauteous.
examples: They often murmur to themselves, they speakTo one another seldom, for their woeBroods maddening inwardly and scorns to wreakItself abroad; and if at whiles it growTo frenzy which must rave, none heeds the clamour,Unless there waits some victim of like glamour,To rave in turn, who lends attentive show.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Alluring beauty or charm (often with sex appeal).
(uncountable) Any excitement, appeal, or attractiveness associated with a person, place, or thing; that which makes something appealing.
examples: The idea of being a movie star has lost its glamour for me.

entries.meaning: Any artificial interest in, or association with, objects, or persons, through which they appear delusively magnified or glorified.
A kind of haze in the air, causing things to appear different from what they really are.
(countable) An item, motif, person, image that by association improves appearance.

verbs.description: glamour (third-person singular simple present glamours, present participle glamouring, simple past and past participle glamoured)
